newsitem.title: ECUADOR: Ecuador says won't sell power transmission lines.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador says won't sell power transmission lines.

text.p: Ecuador's government said Tuesday it has agreed with the state electricity union to modify plans to privatize the Inecel power company and keep transmission lines in state hands.
Secretary for Administration Miguel Salem told reporters that the government would sign an agreement with the Inecel union later Tuesday.
"There is a list of 10 points being drawn up today. These points of consensus will be sent to Congress to modify the law that was passed," Salem said.
He explained that under the agreement, energy transmission lines will remain in state hands.
Congress approved last Thursday a bill outlining a legal framework to sell 39 percent of the assets of state power company Inecel, and offer 10 percent of shares to its workers.
But workers started a hunger strike the next day to pressure the government into changing the law and postponing the sale for three years.
"Among the points that we managed to agree is that Inecel's assets will not be sold, but be capitalized. That fresh capital will go for new projects," an Inecel union spokesman said.
"Transmission will be handled by a state firm and electricity prices will be subsidized for poorer consumers," he added.
Local television quoted a Defense Ministry source saying that the armed forces have told President Abdala Bucaram that they also oppose selling Inecel.
